name: Dummy Deck
description: Temporary deck for routing, server management, and technical validation vocabulary.

cards.sideA: No sabemos donde establecer el enrutamiento.

sideB.text: We don't know where to set the routing.
We aren't sure where to establish the routing.
We don't know where to define the routing.
We don't know where to set the route.

cards.note:
[Routing] refers to the process of selecting a path for traffic in a network.

~We don't know where put the routing~ (Grammar: 'Put' is too generic here. Use technical verbs like [set], [establish], or [configure].)

cards.sideA: No tengo acceso al servidor Linux.

sideB.text: I do not have access to the Linux server.
I don't have access to the Linux server.
I lack access to the Linux server.

cards.note:
[Access] is usually an uncountable noun in this context.

~I don't have an access~ (Grammar: Do not use 'an' with abstract access. You just 'have access'.)

cards.sideA: Nunca he trabajado directamente en el servidor Linux.

sideB.text: I have never worked directly on the Linux server.
I've never worked directly on the Linux server.
I have never done direct work on the Linux server.

cards.note:
Use the preposition [on] when talking about working with servers or platforms.

~In the server~ (While understandable, [on the server] is the standard collocation for software environments.)

cards.sideA: Creo que esos comandos deben usarse en el servidor Linux.

sideB.text: I believe those commands must be used on the Linux server.
I think those commands need to be run on the Linux server.
I believe those commands should be executed on the Linux server.

cards.note:
[Run] and [Execute] are the most common verbs for processing commands.

[Must] implies a strong necessity or requirement.

cards.sideA: Déjame ver el hilo que tengo con Sean.

sideB.text: Let me see the thread I have with Sean.
Let me check the thread I have with Sean.
Let me look at the thread I have with Sean.

cards.note:
A [Thread] refers to a connected series of messages (email, Slack, etc.).

[Check] is a very professional verb for 'ver/revisar' in this context.

cards.sideA: Tenemos el error 404 cuando enviamos la petición al endpoint.

sideB.text: We get a 404 error when we send the request to the endpoint.
We are getting a 404 error when sending the request to the endpoint.
We encounter a 404 error when we hit the endpoint.
We have a 404 error when we send a request to the endpoint.

cards.note:
[Hit] is common technical slang for sending a request to an endpoint.

[Endpoint] is the specific URL where an API service can be accessed.

cards.sideA: Hay una diferencia en las convenciones de nombres.

sideB.text: There is a difference in the naming conventions.
There's a discrepancy in the naming conventions.
The naming conventions are different.

cards.note:
[Naming convention] is the standard term for rules like CamelCase, snake_case, etc.

[Discrepancy] implies a difference that shouldn't exist or causes issues.

~...name conventions~ (Standard term: The correct technical term is [Naming conventions].)

cards.sideA: Tenemos por un lado camel case, y por otro, snake case.

sideB.text: On one hand we have camel case, and on the other, snake case.
We have camel case on one side, and snake case on the other.
There is camel case on one hand, and snake case on the other.

cards.note:
Use [On one hand... and on the other] to contrast two distinct situations.

[Camel case]: `myVariable`
[Snake case]: `my_variable`

~We have on one side camel case...~ (Word order: It is more natural to say 'We have camel case on one side'.)

~...on one side... on the other hand~ (Idiom consistency: Use [On one hand ... on the other hand] OR [On one side ... on the other side]. Do not mix them.)

cards.sideA: Tenemos una palabra adicional en el endpoint.

sideB.text: We have an additional word in the endpoint.
There is an extra word in the endpoint.
We've got an extra word in the endpoint path.

cards.note: [Additional] and [Extra] are generally interchangeable here.

cards.sideA: Tenemos expuesto esto, pero se mapea de otra forma.

sideB.text: We have this exposed, but it maps differently.
We have this exposed, but it is mapped in a different way.
This is exposed, but the mapping is done differently.
We have this exposed, but it gets mapped differently.

cards.note:
To [Expose] an API/Service means to make it available for connection.

To [Map] means to connect or associate one data point/path with another.

cards.sideA: Debe haber una capa intermedia en donde se mapea esto.

sideB.text: There must be a middleware layer where this is mapped.
There has to be an intermediate layer where this mapping happens.
There must be a middle layer where this gets mapped.

cards.note:
[Middleware] is software that acts as a bridge between an operating system or database and applications.

Use [There must be] when you are deducing a fact.

cards.sideA: Debe haber una capa intermedia donde ocurre una traducción de nombres.

sideB.text: There must be a middleware layer where name translation occurs.
There has to be a middleware layer where a name translation takes place.
There must be an intermediate layer where names are translated.
There must be a middleware layer where the name translation happens.

cards.note: In this context, [Translation] refers to transforming data formats or naming conventions (e.g., from CamelCase to SnakeCase).

cards.sideA: Existe una configuración de mapeo desconocida para nosotros.

sideB.text: There is a mapping configuration unknown to us.
There is a mapping configuration we are not aware of.
A mapping config exists that we don't know about.

cards.note:
[Unknown to us] is a formal way to say 'we don't know it'.

[We are not aware of] is professional and very common in meetings.

~There is a unknown...~ (Grammar: Use [an] before vowel sounds like 'unknown'.)

~...configuration to us~ (Word order: Adjectives modifying the noun should be close. Better: 'A mapping configuration [unknown to us]'.)

cards.sideA: Como no se está mapeando, el servidor no puede enrutar la solicitud.

sideB.text: Since it is not being mapped, the server cannot route the request.
Because it isn't being mapped, the server can't route the request.
As it is not mapped, the server is unable to route the request.
Since it is not mapped, the server cannot route the request.

cards.note:
[Since] and [As] are strong alternatives to 'Because' when explaining technical causes.

[Route] (verb) means to send data to a specific destination.

~...can not enroute...~ (Incorrect vocabulary: [En route] is an adverb meaning 'on the way'. The verb is [Route].)

cards.sideA: El endpoint no se está enrutando correctamente.

sideB.text: The endpoint is not being routed correctly.
The endpoint isn't routing properly.
The endpoint is not routing as it should.

cards.note:
[Properly] is a frequent synonym for [Correctly].

Use passive voice [is not being routed] when the system acts on the endpoint.

cards.sideA: El mapeo permite tener searchKeyword…

sideB.text: The mapping allows having searchKeyword...
The mapping enables searchKeyword...
The mapping allows for searchKeyword...

cards.note:
[Allows] or [Enables] are standard verbs to describe what a feature permits.

~The mapping permit~ (Grammar: 'Permit' is more formal/legal; [Allow] is better for software logic.)

~The map allows...~ (Precision: [Mapping] refers to the process or relationship. [Map] usually refers to the specific data structure.)

cards.sideA: El Proxy Inverso es un servicio intermediario.

sideB.text: The Reverse Proxy is an intermediary service.
The Reverse Proxy acts as an intermediary service.
The Reverse Proxy serves as an intermediary.
The Reverse Proxy is a Middleware service.

cards.note: A [Reverse Proxy] sits in front of one or more web servers, intercepting requests from clients.

cards.sideA: El Proxy Inverso se sitúa entre la red pública y la privada.

sideB.text: The Reverse Proxy sits between the public network and the private network.
The Reverse Proxy is located between the public and private networks.
The Reverse Proxy stands between the public network and the internal network.
The Reverse Proxy is between the public internet and the intranet.

cards.note:
[Sits] is a very common technical idiom to describe where a component resides in an architecture.

~...private internet~ (Terminology: The correct term for a private internal network is [Intranet] or [Private Network].)

cards.sideA: Es solo un Manejo de Errores.

sideB.text: It is just Error Handling.
It's simply Error Handling.
It is only Error Handling.

cards.note: [Error Handling] is a specific term for the procedures coded to manage faults.

cards.sideA: Es una validación de Entrada.

sideB.text: It is Input Validation.
It is an Input Validation.
It represents Input Validation.

cards.note: [Input Validation] ensures that properly formed data is entering the workflow.

cards.sideA: Es como una validación de Entrada o Manejo de Errores.

sideB.text: It is like Input Validation or Error Handling.
It's similar to Input Validation or Error Handling.
It acts like Input Validation or Error Handling.

cards.note: [Like] is used to compare the nature or behavior of the code.

cards.sideA: Extrae el texto antes del doble punto.

sideB.text: Extract the text before the colon.
Pull the text occurring before the colon.
Get the text that comes before the colon.

cards.note:
[Colon] (:) is the punctuation mark.

~Double point~ (Incorrect: This is a literal translation of 'dos puntos'. The English term is [Colon].)

cards.sideA: Extrae el número después del doble punto.

sideB.text: Extract the number after the colon.
Get the number following the colon.
Pull the number located after the colon.

cards.note: [Extract] typically implies using a substring method or Regex to isolate data.

cards.sideA: Compatibilidad con versiones anteriores.

sideB.text: Backward Compatibility.
Backwards Compatibility.
Compatibility with previous versions.

cards.note: [Backward Compatibility] is the ability of a system to work with inputs generated by older versions of itself.

cards.sideA: Se delega con el orquestador interno.

sideB.text: It is delegated to the internal orchestrator.
It's delegated to the internal orchestrator.
The task is delegated to the internal orchestrator.

cards.note:
[To delegate] means to assign responsibility or authority.

[Orchestrator] is a system that manages and coordinates automated tasks/services.

~It is delegated with...~ (Incorrect preposition: You delegate a task [to] a system or person.)

cards.sideA: Aquí nos estamos inicializando.

sideB.text: We are initializing here.
The session is being initialized here.
We are performing initialization here.

cards.note: [Initialize] means to set variables, counters, or states to a starting value.

cards.sideA: Nos inicializamos para prevenir errores de sesión.

sideB.text: We initialize to prevent session errors.
We are initializing to avoid session errors.
We initialize to prevent errors in the session.

cards.note: [Prevent] means to stop something from happening before it occurs.

cards.sideA: La inicialización asegura la identidad del usuario en la sesión.

sideB.text: Initialization ensures the user's identity in the session.
Initialization sets the user context.
Initialization secures the user identity within the session.

cards.note:
[Ensures] means to make certain that something happens.

[User context] is a common way to refer to all the data defining the current user.

cards.sideA: La inicialización habilita la visibilidad de los datos según el usuario.

sideB.text: Initialization enables data visibility according to the user.
Initialization allows data visibility based on the user.
Initialization turns on data visibility depending on the user.
Initializing enables data visibility according to the user.

cards.note:
[Enable] is a key technical verb meaning to activate or make possible.

[According to] or [Based on] are correct ways to express dependency.

cards.sideA: La URL debe incluir el protocolo, dominio y ruta.

sideB.text: The URL must include the protocol, domain, and path.
The URL needs to contain the protocol, domain, and path.
We must include the protocol, domain, and path in the URL.

cards.sideA: La URL es la dirección completa para localizar el recurso.

sideB.text: The URL is the complete address to locate the resource.
The URL is the full address used to locate the resource.
A URL serves as the complete address for locating a resource.

cards.note:
**[122]**

[URL] stands for Uniform Resource Locator.

cards.sideA: El Endpoint es la última parte de la URL.

sideB.text: The endpoint is the last part of the URL.
The endpoint is located at the end of the URL.
The final segment of the URL is the endpoint.

cards.note:
**[122]**

The [Endpoint] typically identifies the specific resource or action.

cards.sideA: El Endpoint es el recurso específico al que apunta la URL.

sideB.text: The endpoint is the specific resource the URL points to.
The endpoint represents the specific resource targeted by the URL.
The endpoint is the specific resource the URL is pointing at.

cards.note:
**[122]**

[Points to] is the standard phrasal verb for direction/reference in tech.

~...resource to aim the URL~ (Incorrect phrasing: You [aim at] a target. Better: 'The resource at which the URL is aimed'.)

~...resource to address the URL~ (Incorrect relation: The URL addresses the resource, not the other way around.)

cards.sideA: Endpoint y URL a menudo se usan de forma intercambiable, pero no son lo mismo.

sideB.text: Endpoint and URL are often used interchangeably, but they are not the same.
People often use Endpoint and URL interchangeably, but they aren't the same.
Endpoint and URL are frequently used interchangeably, yet they differ.
Endpoint and URL are often used in an interchangeable way, but they are not the same.

cards.note:
**[122]**

[Interchangeably] means switching one for the other.

cards.sideA: Necesitamos la ruta, dominio y protocolo de la URL.

sideB.text: We need the URL's path, domain, and protocol.
We require the path, domain, and protocol of the URL.
We need the URL protocol, domain, and path.

cards.sideA: En la ruta de la URL está incluido el endpoint.

sideB.text: The endpoint is included in the URL path.
The URL path includes the endpoint.
The endpoint is part of the URL path.

cards.note:
**[122]**

Technically, the endpoint is often the final segment of the path.

~In the URL path is included the endpoint~ (Syntax error: English word order is Subject + Verb. Better: 'The endpoint is included in the URL path'.)
